author: Straw Hat

text: This is your first time playing this level. The catchy beat begins. You crawl slowly through the vents. You find yourself looking down at the shitter. Your eye catches movement. A head with a green hat! It's time to clean the manure out from between this commie's ears. pew goes the PP7. A puff of white. The hat flies off. TENSION....you wait. Nothing. He scratches his head and continues staring into the oblivion of the bathroom stall door. Your heart beats hard. "Finish the job, James.", you whisper to yourself. pew "gak!" thump. Tango down.  You feel like a bad ass. This was Goldeneye.

I don't understand why people stare at when I'm about to enter a public restroom, and then enter a public stall. I enter very stealthily, like a catwoman.

Then I get on top of the toilet with pepper spray, looking at all the vents.
If all is clear, I sit and proceed.

I thank this game for that, as I will never die while sitting on a toilet.

Muah xoxo 007

text:
Yes, it was. But it was not the 'FIRST...FIRST PERSON SHOOTER GAME...EVER!!!!'

There were tonnes of FPSs before Goldeneye
author: Christopher Barnard

text:
Um... no....

There were a tonne of great first person shooters to come before this- Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D, among others. In fact, Half Life came out in the same year as Goldeneye, which I would say has been more influential.

Still, this is definitely a pinnacle of the genre, and it not only proved that the FPS could work on consoles, but could excell!

text: Good man, extremely well said. My nostalgia for these titles stems directly from the music.
author: RRJ1

text: I agree 100%.  Great games always have great soundtracks.  Music sets the atmosphere for the game from start to finish.  Even in the 8-bit era, certain music tracks at certain points in a game seem like the music is actually willing you to beat difficult areas in the game.  MM2's Wily Stage 2 song comes to mind.  You rarely get that type of epic feeling in games today, though it does happen in games like Okami and Shadow of the Colossus whose entire OSTs are made of complete & utter win.
